awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Learning to perform consistently in human/multi-robot teams
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on practical deployment of human/multi-robot teams in situations where robots can explore regions that are unsuitable for humans. For example, a team of "rescue" robots can sweep through a collapsed building searching for victims and transmit their positions to human first-responders outside. Managing a human/multi-robot team in a dynamic environment is a challenging problem. Not only is the world mutable, but also the team can experience altered membership because a robot gets lost or a human operator needs rest---the world is changing, and so is the team that is exploring that world.

The goal of this research is to develop strategies for human/multi-robot teams to learn to perform consistently and effectively. Three primary aims will be pursued: first, to mitigate changes in team composition via a practical framework for institutional memory that remembers and uses past experiences; second, to model and record expertise for later use by learning behaviors performed by a human operator; and third, to distribute tasks among team members efficiently by providing a balanced mechanism for social choice. The novel approach of this project is applicable to a broad spectrum of human/multi-robot, and human/multi-agent teams, by integrating institutional memory, learning from human teammates, and resolving conflict among differing perspectives. The strategies will be evaluated using a human/multi-robot testbed comprised of one human operator plus a heterogeneous set of inexpensive, limited-function robots. Although each individual robot has restricted mobility and sensing capabilities, together the team members constitute a multi-function, human/multi-robot facility.

This project addresses important challenges in robust intelligence, including behavior modeling, learning from experience, making coordinated decisions, and reasoning under uncertainty. Expected outcomes include strategies for human/multi-robot teams that learn to collaborate effectively under a variety of conditions and can maintain their performance despite run-time changes in team membership, as well as knowledge about how people interact with robot teams. Broader impacts include providing access to a networked experimental testbed for remote collaborators; publishing proven curricular materials on multi-robot teams addressed to graduate, undergraduate and high school students; involving undergraduates in research activities; and working with existing contacts at local museums to demonstrate results to the general public.

por.por_cntn:
This "HRTeam" project is motivated by the growing trend toward practical deployment of human/robot teams, particularly in situations where robots can explore regions unsafe for humans. Rescue robots can search collapsed buildings for victims whose positions they transmit to human first-responders. Demining robots can search post-conflict areas for anti-personnel landmines and transmit their positions to human deminers. Typically, one or two expensive, multi-function robots are deployed to search. A lost robot halts search operations and can impose a heavy cost, both in terms of equipment and human life. The alternative envisioned in this project employs a multi-agent approach that instead deploys a team of cheaper robots whose combined abilities provide diverse functionality.

Managing a team of robots in a dynamic environment is a challenging problem, for either a human operator or a fully autonomous multi-agent system. Further, in the real world, a human/multi-robot team experiences changes in membership, either unexpected (robots break) or anticipated (people require rest). Thus, the world is changing, and so is the team that is exploring that world. This adds a further level of difficulty to managing the team. This project has considered precisely this problem.

The overarching research goal of this research is to learn to perform consistently in a human/multi-robot team, despite run-time changes in team composition. The major goals of the project have been to develop a practical framework for institutional memory and shared decision-making in a human-robot team; to track and model operator interactions in a multi-robot team; and to provide a balanced mechanism for social choice in a multi-robot team, distributing tasks among team members efficiently.

Research on developing a framework for shared decision making has focused on the use of argumentation-based dialogue as a means to support human interaction with robots. Experimental results have compared supervisory vs peer interaction in human-robot teams. Results clearly show that peer interaction promotes the human feeling more integrated with the team, e.g., when allowed to make joint decisions with robots using argumentation-based dialogue, as opposed to robots acting autonomously (without sharing decisions with the human team member). Performance metrics are significantly better when the human-robot team works together in a peer relationship, rather than when humans act as supervisors. Additional collaborative work has involved development of the SemaFORR cognitive architecture for robot control, where robots learn from experience how to select correct actions in order to achieve certain goals, blending input from their sensors, behavioral memory and human collaborators. Results are documented in a number of peer-reviewed conference and journal publications.

Research on modeling operator interaction has focused on effective ways to measure situational awareness of a human team member faced with missions of varying complexity. Experimental results are preliminary, but show that certain types of missions are more easily handled by the human, despite measuring as more complex in traditional complexity scales that were designed from the robot team perspective. This line of research included development and validation of a human-centric method for measuring task complexity, which contrasts with traditional task complexity methods that are designed from a robot-centric perspective. This methodology was validated through two user studies, documented in a PhD dissertation and several peer-reviewed conference publications.

Research on balancing effort in a multi-robot team has focused on identifying and assessing a range of auction-based mechanisms for task allocation. Experimental results have shown the need to consider how the team mission evolves over time when selecting a task allocation mechanism. Our results illustrate that when new tasks arise as the team is executing its mission, the advantage of using more complex auction-based mechanisms are eroded. This amplifies our early results which demonstrated that, to fully understand the performance of task allocation mechanisms, it is not sufficient to only consider which tasks are allocated to the team members, but that it is necessary to also consider the execution of the tasks. Overall, by studying mechanisms for the allocation of robot-routing tasks on a spectrum of scenarios, we have shown that mechanisms which perform poorly when allocation of a static set of tasks alone is considered, can perform relatively well when metrics relating to task execution are considered and when the tasks evolve over time. This research involved a user study which measured the impact of argumentation-based dialogue in conflict resolution and reaching agreement in collaborative tasks. Results were documented in a PhD dissertation and a number of peer-reviewed conference and journal papers.
